column3: Chasing an elite mark, I presume. Adventurers hither, adventurers thither. Soon we shall have to write \x02\x1a\x02\x02\x03you\x02\x1a\x02\x01\x03 into the Raimdelle Codex.
Tell me about the rank B elite mark. (Phecda)
Tell me about the rank A elite mark. (Girtab)
Tell me about the rank S elite mark. (Thousand-cast Theda)
I am the elite mark hunter. I contemplate the codex, hunt the hideous, and preserve the peace.
And of course, I bag the bounty of Allied Seals when I do slay one of those mischief-makers.
If you have something to ask, don't tarry. The elite mark waits for no one.
In fact, sometimes it will seem that a rank S elite mark appears for no one. \xe2\x80\x9cS\xe2\x80\x9d would be the most feral of the elite marks. They are ranked by danger, you see.
bxe2\x80\x9cA bear of unusual size from the distant heights of Abalathia's Spine
column4: Phecda's southward migration has not been a happy one for the Black Shroud."

column3: \xe2\x80\x9cIts uncouth appetite has emptied whole areas of the forest of edibles and game, and no hunter has returned with evidence of a cull\xe2\x94\x80or returned at all. Phecda may be distinguished from its more peaceable cousins by the constant slick of blood upon its claws.\xe2\x80\x9d
\xe2\x80\x9cGirtab, the mightiest among mites that ravage the North Shroud.
\xe2\x80\x9cPainstaking field observations have revealed that the Girtab prefers its prey fresh, and keeps a living larder of two- and four-legged meals artfully held fast in a web.\xe2\x80\x9d
\xe2\x80\x9cBotanists call Thousand-cast Theda as well grown a specimen of ochu as ever has been recorded in the North Shroud, but the foolishness of botanists is a fact well known and oft deplored.

\xe2\x80\x9cMost species of this carnivorous family of bindweed use scent to lure their insect prey. Theda, however, is a plant notably lacking in patience and has evolved tentacle-like vines to pluck fish from water, and grows outsized on its rich meals.
bxe2\x80\x9cAlong with the fisherfolk of the Shroud
column4: Thousand-cast Theda is the main predator of venomous stingrays. Theda's other favored prey is
column6: the fisherfolk of the Shroud. Hunters suspect a connection
column7: but the foolishness of hunters is a fact well known.\xe2\x80\x9d"
